description.text: Joby ( http://joby.com/gorillapod ) makes fantastic, versatile tripods that can stand on rough surfaces and wrap around sturdy objects. The design is modular, consisting of many short links with ball joint attachments. Because of this, it seems like a perfectly amenable for 3D printing. With the ability to print the GorillaPod links, makers can use this technology for anything requiring a flexible mount.

There is a Camera Mount with hole and head-lock for a 1/4 inch bolt which secures the camera.  The Camera Mount has three ball heads which the GorillaPod links snap onto.  
I don't have a 3D printer, so I haven't been able to physically experiment with this design. I'm not sure how well the joints will come together and how much friction there will be when they are together.  One idea to maintain friction in the joints is to use the rubberized tool handle coating when assembling the links.
If anyone prints out these designs, I would love to hear how it went.

comments.text: After a pass through netfabb to close up the holes, and flip all the normals, I made two of these. It's a good idea, but the base is too tight, it needs to be opened up a little to allow for tolerance. I snapped both pieces trying to fit them together.

description.text: It's a ring created using a icosahedron as a jewel on top.

I've tryied couple of different ways to place the ring on the makerBot's bed. The best result came with this model. 
The ring at this model is a size 8. If you would like to adjust it you can add or subtract material from the ring part. 
I made white and black versions of it. I like the black the best. 
I recommend using an outside raft support to print it clean. It comes out ok without a support too but not as smooth as one might like. 
Enjoy :)

title: Crossbar dual E3D hot end upgrade for Mankati Fullscale XT

description.text:
OBSOLETE! New version, mounted directly on the crossbar.
Final version, it will get updates if / when necessary. It even enlarges the height of build volume due to the much shorter hot end mount. Very easy to mount, it is designed to be changed in 1 minute or less.
Both fans are oriented to the back of the printer and powered through 2 spring contacts, allowing for easy fan removal. On top there are 2 screws to fix a PCB to hold all the wire connectors. Also designed to allow quick change of the whole assembly. All are M3 nuts and screws.

Flip the parts to suit your printing options. You have 3 parts:
  • fan shroud for the double 30mm fans that come with the E3D's
  • main body that holds the XY bushings and hotend plus quick connect PCB
  • brackets to fix the two E3D hotends
    • Print parts, fix the two spring loaded contacts to the main body.
    Fix the two small FR4 1.5mm PCB's on the fan shroud and solder both fan cables in parallel. Assemble hotend per manufacturers directions.
    Slide the hotends in the body, fix them with the brackets and screws, Finish the wiring to the top PCB, to your liking. I would suggest changing the Mankati PTFE Bowden tube for a better one and also keeping it as short as possible. Slide the fan shroud on the hotend. For the fans, use the right (second) fan cable, it is always powered, as it should be. Don't forget to print and install the longer Z end-stop holder but fix it upside down, as it is now, this design gaines a few mm in Z height. Click for firmware using the new thermistors
    Follow the link and at the bottom of the page click "Build it" and download the whole zip file, extract .hex file and flash from Cura.
    Finally, you will have true temperature shown (original Mankati firmware was showing 30C too much to protect the lousy hotends). Never shut down the printer before the hotend cools down to room temperature!

comments.text: How is this set up working out for you?
comments.author: DMP_3D

comments.text:
It's the best hotend for me. No problems whatsoever with any type of material.
Mankati was upgraded some time ago to CoreXY movement and produces spectacular prints since then.
As with any printer out there, using a dust cleaner on the filament will save you a lot of headaches.
comments.author: DMP_3D

Just a simple figurine/toy creature I put together, adapted from a 3D animation project.  The rendered image shows what it looks like skinned in Blender 3D; it could be painted once printed to resemble this, or you could do something completely different.  It eats books, if that's of interest to anyone.
This is my first CAD project, so let me know if it doesn't work properly, and I'll try to fix it!
I need to do some research on licensing options, but while I currently reserve all rights, you're free to download, print, and use the model for most any non-commercial purposes as far as I'm concerned.  If someone does want to do something commercial with it, drop me a line; I'd be interested to hear about it!

• Load the file into a 3D printer
  • Print!
  • Optionally, paint or otherwise decorate the figurine for added awesomeness (you can use the rendered image I added as reference or do something completely different!) o):D)b
  • Also optionally, print out 50 of them and take peculiar photographs of yourself being attacked by a horde of tiny aliens to post on the glorious intertubes u)u.u)o

title: Alternate Arms for Mini Loose Filament Spool

description.text: I have loads of short runs of 3mm Faberdashery filament and the Mini Loose Filament Spool (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:293382) looked like a good way to go with keeping them tidy. But I needed some more slots and slightly larger arms so I made these. The holes fit 3mm filament and I also added some at the top of the arms. The 70_70_35 version will hold around 20m per slot. Just remember to wind the filament on the right way so the flat side is against the back of the printer. I wound 2 lots before I realised I had done it wrong, doh! Edit: arms are now the correct height - 6mm (thanks arachno7)

comments.text: This would work great for me, but I need  a 1.75 version. Can you upload it?
comments.author: vaqueram

comments.text: Great mod to the mini filament spool.  Just wanted to comment that I couldn't get your print to fit with the original spool holder.  The connector part of your arm models seem to be 1mm wider than the original.  Scaled the print by .8571 in the Z dimension and everything worked.  Thanks!
comments.author: arachno7

comments.text:
Fixed!
:)
comments.author: arachno7

comments.text:
Thanks! Yes you are completely correct they are both 1mm to tall and I'm baffled as to why they are. My original cad files are 6mm so I must have randomly scaled them at some point. I'm just going to fix and update them. Thanks for pointing that out.
Cheers
Dan
comments.author: arachno7

remixed_from.author: cerberus333
remixed_from.title: B9 Environmental Control Robot (Lost in Space)

title: Lost In Space Robot - B9 - Parted

description.text:
Robot from the TV show Lost In Space.The model was sliced up into separate parts to make it easy to print with most FFF/FDM hobby 3DPrinters. The file was derived from the file uploaded by cerberus333. It was chopped up and repaired using NetFabb. This Thing is a featured Thing Of the Week on the 3D Printing Today Podcast!
Http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com.
Shows are now posted on our feed twice weekly!

Having B9 chopped up makes it much easier to print. No supports needed for the feet, legs, face and dome. The body and the scanners DO need supports.
Each part has a flat surface on the bottom for easy build plate stick as well as easy glue assembly.
The scanner part is exceptionally fragile in the current scale. Scaling up a bit should make it much sturdier.

title: Snake Cube Puzzle, Printed Fully Assembled and Ready to Solve
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: First you print it, then you solve it. The first photo shows the snake cube solved, the second photo shows the snake cube as it comes off the 3D printer. Fold the printed version into the final version, no strings, wires, motors, screws, glue or cranks, just frustration. However, as the photos show, it can be folded into a cube. This snake cube puzzle prints fully assembled and ready to solve. To increase the difficulty, I paused the printer at 10mm and changed from white to black filament. I saw this video http://woodgears.ca/puzzles/snake_cube.html and this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10486, but both used string to hold the cubes together. I was looking to build a fully assembled ready to solve snake cube puzzle and, well, this is it. Hope you print and solve it. Designed using Sketchup 8 and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42.

Print this thing then figure out how to fold it into a cube.  
Good luck!

title: Revell Big One Pro RC Helicopter - Top Blade Gear and Hub

description.text:
The old gear was loose on the shaft due to many crashes and I wasn't able to fasten it anymore on the shaft.
This replacement 94 teeth 1.6 pitch gear + hub fixed everything!

Simply slide the hub into the gear, drop the bearing in the hub (a tight fit) slide the shaft and fasten to shaft of a Revell RC Coaxial Big One Pro RC Helicopter! Make sure your first run is smooth because the gear will need some breakin' in, but it flies superbly after this break in phase! Make sure to print without extra shells! These are very very tiny teeth and you want them to be filled with plastic (Skeinforge has some problem if you put extra shells!

This is a makerbot-printable dremel based milling machine, and my entry for the make/makerbot contest. I wasn't able to finish printing it before the deadline, so it is untested, and should be regarded as a prototype. After I finish printing, I will release a revised version that will fix any bugs that come up. 
The axises move on dovetail slides. When completed, it will have a travel of 11cm on the x axis, 5cm on the y axis, and 10cm on the z axis. 
So far, I have printed half of the x axis and part of the y axis. The dovetail slide moves freely with little slack or wobble, even though the print warped. This makes the rest of the machine look very feasible, and I'm confident that it will be able to machine aluminum (shallow cuts, of course) when it's finished.

This is a prototype, and has not been fully tested. Although it should work in principle, it is considerably less polished than a finished piece should be, and there are bound to be problems. I don't recommend that you build it just yet. After it has been printed and the bugs have been ironed out, I will release a finished version.

comments.text: is it food safe?
comments.author: donb

comments.text: ABS is considered both food safe and drug safe by the FDA, and it's also dishwasher safe.
comments.author: donb

comments.text: I think that it'd be more accurate to say that ABS can be food safe, but all of the filament that I've seen hasn't been labeled food safe, and conventional wisdom on Thingiverse is that you shouldn't use ABS for plates, forks, cups, etc., because it could release some nasty chemicals into the food/water. PLA is generally considered food safe, but even then I'd be concerned that it hasn't been handled safely. For example, if you print both ABS and PLA using the same extruder, arguably it'd be a bad idea to print and use PLA foodware. Companies that well plastics sell different specific products that are or are not food-safe, with different spec sheets, pricing, etc., so personally I wouldn't chance it.
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: I can't say for sure, but ABS is supposed to be food safe I think... Well I'm not dead yet.. :)

title: Zelda: Ocarina of Time Spiritual Stones

description.text:
These are the three Spiritual Stones from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of time (Kokiri's Emerald, Goron's Ruby, and Zora's Sapphire).   
I made them because I couldn't find any good models of the stones online anywhere - none of them looked accurate. These were ripped straight from the game with the 1964 emulator, the VRML plugin, and Blender. They were then cleaned up in Solidworks to fill in missing surfaces, knit them into a solid, and orient them to print well.

Each Spiritual Stone has the stone and its holder. The stones are simple enough that they can be printed with no support material. For prettiest results, print them with one shell and no infill, in a translucent color.
The holders are a bit more complicated. I've included models with integrated support that work great on my Replicator 2, but if you want to use your printer's own support generation, I've also added models without it. For Kokiri's Emerald, print one stone and one holder. When assembling it, the emerald has a particular orientation. It's a bit confusing, so I've included a picture that should help. The Goron's Ruby is easiest. One stone, one holder. They should slide together pretty snugly, but if not, a dab of super glue on the bottom should help. Zora's Sapphire is the most annoying. Print three of the stones, three of the little accent gems (in the same color as the holder), and one holder. Use a clear glue to carefully glue the gems in their respective areas. You might need to use an exacto knife to trim the tabs a bit and make them fit well. In addition to the stones, I made a base that they can be mounted on. A bit of hot glue works well for this (and if you want to take them off later, rubbing alcohol makes it lose its adhesion).

title: Googly Eyes Bookmark
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this in OpenSCAD after seeing a similar one that one of my kids had. It's rendered at 0.66mm thick, and I print it at 0.33mm layer height. 
It's a pretty quick print and would probably make a great demo piece, too. 
The photos of the red bookmark show the older version, which had no nose. The blue one is the latest version. 
UPDATE 9/1/12: I fixed the centering on the slots, brought the eyes and hands in a little bit closer, and added a nose.

1) Print (0.33 layer height works well)
2) Insert 10mm googly eyes. Mine didn't even require glue -- they're held in quite nicely by the ridges on the layers. 
3) Go read a book.

comments.text: I'm sorry you guys didn't get what you needed.  The intent was not to blow air on the filament directly as it is extruded.  The goal was to blow air on it after it was laid down.  I was having issues with printed elements that were small and repeatedly had hot filament applied on top of them and them not being cooled prior to the next layer.  Knowing what I know now, I could envision modifying the nozzle shape....I'll take a whack at it when I can.
comments.author: plexus

comments.text: That makes sense Rockstar. sorry to have been dismissive. i can see how the part was made for something specific. i actually printed it and modified it. i dont have the ability to edit STLs so i did it old school - with a band saw. :D i cut the end of the nozzle off, long enough it wouldn't hit the print bed and cut the fan holder off where it goes down at an angle so i could raise the fan up higher. the idea was to have a funnel that would basically point right at the point where its printing with perhaps 1cm of side blow on either side of the hot end tip. i was actually envisioning a system with a removable fan nozzle end: you can run it with the narrow end of the nozzle off to get wider blow and more power due to less back pressure, or press on the narrower part of the blower that aims right at the hot end tip for more localized cooling. can you do it???? :D
comments.author: RockstarAlchemist

Assists in helping you calibrate the amount of material you will extrude through the printed, plastic extruder.

Print out both pieces of the extruder measuring tool.  Slip the base through the screw hole and then the feeder through the base.  Using calipers, measure the hole on the feeder tool from the base to the top.  Mark the filament then extrude it 6 times at 5mm per time.  Once it's done measure (using calipers) the top of the mark to the base of the feeder and you have your distance travelled.  Use that measurement to calibrate your bot.
You may have to sand down the edges if your printrbot calibration isn't very precise for the feeder hole on the base and the holes on the feeder that the filament travel's through.
In the pictures given, I measured a distance of 39.37 from the base to the top of the feeder inner hole, and after 6x5mm extrudes I measure 10.57mm to the top of the mark.  My extrusion was 28.8mm; I'm off by 1.2mm of material for every 30mm I extrude.  With that I can adjust as needed.

I printed a selection of fan ducts for my Mendel90. Some of them didn't fit and others just didn't work, so I designed my own. I have copied some of the best features from other designs and merged them into a model that will fit on the Mendel90 using a couple of adapters for mounting. Update - April 2013 - my original fan duct was getting a little overheated so I finally got around to redesigning a slightly longer version which centres the nozzle better. Update 2 - the all-metal E3D hot end needs a cooling fan and shroud fitted to it. There was not enough space to fit this so I have released an updated low-profile version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91931

The fan duct will end up sitting quite close to the hot end so should be printed in ABS.
The Mendel90 X carriage has no fan mounting points so I decided to adapt my Wade's Block Riser thing (needed for the herringbone gears) to provide two mounting holes for the fan duct. This is a quick and dirty hack designed to allow me to get the fan working quickly. The whole design can definitely be improved and should be consider a work in progress.
Screw the 60 mm fan to the duct with short self-tapping screws.
Bolt the fan duct to the bracket.
Fix the bracket to the riser plate with two more bolts.
I didn't have a spare controller pin on my Sanguinololu (since adding the LCD panel and click controller) so I bought a Zalman Single Fan Controller from Amazon for Ã‚Â£4 to control the fan speed manually. The long ribbon cable provided rides piggybacked onto the main X-ribbon and the controller is stuck to the side of the X motor block.
Future improvements planned include redesigning the riser plate to lock under the X belt clamp and adjusting the duct shape to get the nozzle centred better in the ring.

If you have a pet hamster, you know that they like to run in their exercise wheel - a LOT, at NIGHT and often the wheel SQUEAKS.  Here is a design for a (hopefully) squeakless hamster wheel that uses a 608 bearing.  I don't (yet) have a 3-d printer, so no photos.  I made sure there were not non-manifold points.

Makerbot - print 4 Quarter Wheel pieces, plain or with ventillation holes.  Lay sections to form an entire wheel.  Hot glue along the edges.  Shove a 608 bearing in the middle hole.  Use 4 short m4 bolts and 8 washers to secure 608 bearing into the wheel.  Thread m8 bolt through the middle hole (use those washers), through the bars of the cage and fasten with the m8 nut.  Use washers as needed to keep the wheel turning freely.
Mendel/reprap - print entire wheel at once and continue as above.
You can add more holes for ventilation or decoration.  I wonder if you could mount tiny, powerfull magnets on the back side of the wheel and try to generate a current through an external wire winding.  I think it should be able to light an LED or two...

comments.text: Is there a manageable way to enlarge the diameter of the wheel? If I simply scaled it that would enlarge the bearing hole too.

description.text:
Moved to http://goo.gl/qQ6qHy This is scale model of the Minecraft character 'Steve' - that's the character you play in the game. It's based on Irdfang's 'Guy' model, but I decided it needed more character, so I've added hair, clothes and a face. In total, the changes the scad file are:
  • Added hair and face
  • Added a shirt to the body, with a cut out for the neckline
  • Added sleeves to the arms
  • Made it easier to produce individual parts of the model
  • Flipped the Z axis so that it's the right way up
  • Cleaned the programming for readability and reuse of code.
    • The creeper in the photo is thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29518 Design removed and replaced with the flat disk you see, feel free to email for the original if you want it. See following link for details http://traverseda.wordpress.com/2014/05/23/makerbot-blatently-steals-and-patents-a-community-design/ For alternatives to thingiverse see http://www.reddit.com/r/3Dprinting/comments/26do2z/alternative_repositories_to_thingiverse/

Ultimately you need a head, body, 2 legs, 2 arms and a piece of equipment for him to hold. I find it best to print a head, a single body + legs, and then the 2 arms.
If you want you can print the body and legs separately, but I've had no problems on the Ultimaker with the overhang, printing at about 85. For a 'traditional' steve you should print one of each arm type, but you could alternatively print two 'tool arms' if you want him to be able to wield two things. The arms are completely interchangeable left-to-right. Once you have your pieces join the legs/arms/body with short pieces of wire & glue, attach the head at a suitable angle & glue, and insert an appropriate tool. I've not updated any of the equipment files provided by Irdfang, so just grab the STL's from his version. If you're an openscad user you can download the scad file and play with producing the head, body, arms, legs, or body+legs files in whichever forms you prefer.

Add a fan to shed some degrees off your 3D printer stepper motor.
My y-axis motor runs the hottest of the five so I'm adding a fan to cool it down a bit. I may also add one to the x-axis motor too.
Uses a standard 40mm 12v fan.
The fan housing is a press fit on the end of the stepper motor and has captive nuts for the fan screws. The housing has a step inside to set a 5mm gap at the rear of the motor. The idea is the air will enter through the fan and exit via the four side vents.
Just hook it staight onto the 12 volt supply and run it whenever you are using the printer.

Print it, press the four nuts into the base and mount your fan.
The whole lot will press onto the end of a NEMA17 type stepper motor.
Extend the fan wires and connect them to the 12 volt supply to your electronics board.

author: cjfowler70

description.text:
Same as the previous idea but this time with a cheap and nasty VGA card fan. These great little fans cost less than a buck and work really well for small cooling jobs. I also used a couple on my printer head.
The fan housing is a press fit on the end of the stepper motor and the housing has a step inside to set a 5mm gap at the rear of the motor. The air enters through the fan and exit via the four side vents.

Print it out.
Press the VGA fan into the back - no screws needed, if it is slightly loose put a drop of glue in each corner but mine came out as a good press fit.
Press the housing on the end of you NEMA17 type stepper motor - its a nice snug fit.
Extend the fan wires and connect them to a 12 volt supply like the one that feeds your electronics.

title: XYZ Da Vinci 3D Printer filament cartridge counter resetter

description.text:
One of my cartridges died a couple of days ago (printer was showing 0m left, where there was still filament in the cartridge), so I made this simple cartridge counter resetter that snaps at the bottom and resets the internal eeprom counter. It uses an Arduino Pro Mini PCB, spring-action push pins and a 3v button cell with some very basic code (originally written by [email protected] and updated with more features and bug fixes for version J by me). Please note -- someone is selling my design on eBay (I do not sell on eBay) -- they are using my artwork and misrepresenting my design against the CC licence. Please do not support these guys.
The original kit (if you wan it) is always available @ http://wctek.com/shop complete with sundries ...

description.text: When I saw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:112117 by jetpad I said, hey, that looks like a gold classifier. I wasn't the only one. Problem was that it didn't stack. Now it does. I also made the grid more customizable, as I figured a 10mm grid wouldn't work with .4-.5mm thick grids. While it slows down printing, I have the grills passing through each other instead of stacked, and the stacking brim has an angled growth area so it should be able to print without supports.

Adjust the parameters in Customizer or by downloading the .scad file.  
Pay attention to the printer parameters to get the best results.  I think this will print without supports.  
I suspect that hole sizes of less than 2 or 3 mm are not going to be much use - an empty frame with a proper classifier mesh would be needed for finer sizes.

title: New Mars Rover using the new tool OOML!!

description.text:
Mars Rover. Here is a new Mars Rover design created from OOML (Oriented-Object Mechanical Library). A very easy way to develop prototypes! This design uses a double printed bearing and two springs. Also, it is ready to be controlled by an Arduino UNO or a SkyMega microcontroller, with a place for the battery. This Mars Rover uses Futaba S3003 servos and a Bluetooth module. All these components are important because of the shape of the parts; however, you can modify it and buy your own prototype. With OOML tool modification of design is very simple! Oriented-Object Mechanical Library is a new mechanical design tool, based on C++, which makes it easier for users to share designs, besides acquiring the power of this language. Whether you know C++ programming or not, I encourage you to test it. Take a look at http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php?id=start I attach the OOML, OpenSCAD and STL files, besides the Autocad planes. The OpenSCAD files are results of compiling the OOML file, so these codes are uncommented. You can see a video of the prototype in the next link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCLwgrm9mkM The Mars Rover has been designed by: Alberto Valero:
thingiverse.com/avalero Mario Almagro:
thingiverse.com/Mario_AC

To modify any part, you should download and install OOML tool from this link: http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php?id=download:start To build the original Mars Rover prototype you should follow the steps: 1- Print all parts. Some parts need to be printed two or three times. There are three parts of each wheel design, and there are two parts of the 1, 2, 3, 6, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16 designs. 2- Attach the second and third parts to the first part by using the side holes. 3- Attach the fourth part to the first part through top holes. 4- Attach the seventh part to the sixth part, and this last part to fourth part. 5- Introduce the eleventh part in the central hole of the first part; attach the eleventh part to the twelfth part; and this to the thirteenth part. 6- Finally, set the servos and set the last part on the top of the last servo. This will be the spring support. 7- In addition, use the fifteenth and sixteenth parts to control the angle of inclination of the base.

title: Sponge holder to dry your smelly kitchen sponges

description.text:
A simple concept with some useful design features, there are water escape paths and room for air to move. It can hold 3 sponges.  
There are 2 sizes to choose, The small one is for the smallest of sponge. The larger one will fit most average sponges. It's simply a 170% enlargement of the smaller one. Small is about 70mm wide, large is about 120mm. Just make the bigger one bigger if you're unsure.  
The idea is to keep your sponges dry so they don't grow harmful bacteria which you then wipe all over your dirty bench growing more bacteria. So wring them out well after each use and the bacteria will find it hard to grow. Sure there is good bacteria, but not much on you kitchen bench especially if you're a meat eater! Every few days your sponges should be soaked in boiling water (smell them before & after to experience the instant death of bacteria, ahhh). To clean the sponge holder you would need to use a chemical like bleach or baking soda etc although there shouldn't be much surface area that is in contact with the sponge.  
Happy sponging lol  
This was made in Design Spark Mechanical, and it was the first thing I've made using that software, my 3d skills are minimal but I got my idea out there ;) Is pretty straightforward to use and I'd have to recommend it if you're a newbie to 3D design, changing the dimensions of things afterwards can be a challenge though, but it has great tools to put rounded corners on things which print much neater then square corners, took about an hour of messing around to make this thing.

description.text:
After having one of my mechanical endstops break, I decided to beef up the limit switch a bit. Using soldered leads to hold a limit switch in place is just asking for failures. Here are end stop reinforcers for the X, Y, and Z axes on MBI printers. MBI Mechanical Endstop:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4971 Should also work with most clones. Tested on an R2x using MBI's "mechanical endstop" and Flash Forge's "axis sensor."

The X reinforcer requires 1x M3x0.5 screw with length 16mm.
The Y reinforcer requires 2x M3x05 screws with length 16mm.
The Z reinforcer uses stock R2x hardware. I use Carl's Alu X-ends and the Bottleworks relacement Y endstop bracket. But others have tested this with stock R2x parts. Thanks to Scott B for suggesting an improvement for the MBI X-ends. I've updated the STLs so all three reinforcers will work with standard 16mm screws and stock X-ends without modification. I printed mine on an R2x at 100% scale, in ABS with a 0.4mm nozzle, with 2 shells at 60mm/s and 30% infill at 120mm/s. But the part is so small your acceleration settings basically control how fast it prints. Slow is good. Over-extrusion is bad. The X axis reinforcer "nubbin" may print poorly due to insufficient cooling time for each layer. I haven't had any fit issues from that. But you can turn on purge walls or add a sacrificial tower to the print to give extra time for layer cooling. Machines with significant backlash may have trouble with the smaller features. Make sure your belts are tight, and don't be afraid to drill out the screw holes if you need to.

comments.text:
Nice job on this. I had just bought a riprap replacement to keep on hand when I noticed my X and Y bending up a little. I would have had to slightly modify the one I bought, but it would have worked.
Now I may never need to use the replacement switch with this installed. They may never break,mat least not physically.
comments.author: scottd

comments.text:
The X-limit reinforcement probably saved me from losing a couple of microswitches. On both of my machines (R2X) the switches had already been bent up quite a few degrees, and the constant flexing probably would have fatigued the the leads leading to breakage.
Thanks Tempo502!

I only kept the middle chainring on my bicycle because I was barely using the two others anyway.
This chainguard replaces the outer chainring and prevent the chain going off the chainring on this side.
It fits the 5 bolts 94BCD crankset (aka compact mountain bike cranckset) with a 32 teeth chainring.

I used 3mm plexiglas.
I guess multiply wood might be stylish if you have the right style of bicycle :o)
Just replace your outer chainring with this disk.
You might want to remove your inner ring and front shifter but then you still need to figure out a way to avoid your chain falling inside.
This accessory might make a perfect job to prevent the chain falling inside: http://www.dsb-bonandrini.com/prodotti_scheda.aspx?s=3&ss=10&m=49&p=1267
but i would prefer doing something myslelf. If you design something please tell me.

title: Whirlpool Part 358684 Strike Lid Switch Extension

description.text:
Recently my cheap Whirlpool LSR8233JQO washing machine stopped entering the spin cycle, which left me in a bit of a predicament since the basket was filled with water and I had no real way of easily draining it.   
Conversely, after investigating the timing unit --- the evil and expensive part 3953146 --- and determining that it was more economical to either build my own timing unit from a raspberry pi and some AC relays I had laying around the house or to buy another cheap washing machine, I discovered via googling that the spinning problem can also occur because the switch lid --- part 3949237 --- stops working.  
Likewise, after examining the switch lid --- noting that I decided to use a screwdriver to push the switch lid down since a complete disassembly of the washing machine would be required to gain access to the lid switch --- the spin cycle started working again, thus I discovered that the part 358684 strike lid switch was not toggling the part 3949237 lid switch.  
Now, at this point, while some people might have decided to disassemble the machine and address this problem more directly, I opted to create a part using my 3D printer that would extend the Whirlpool Part 358684 Lid Switch in order to fix the problem and the results of my labors are provided here.

This model was done in scad and files are included. This model could use some more refinement feel free to modify it if needed. I printed this model using support material; however, you will need some small files --- harbor fright has a nice cheap set --- and a hobby knife to clean up the material before using this part. It might be possible to print this part without support material, but I do not recommend it without doing some work in SCAD first. Beyond this, I like to run my printer slow and steady since my print deck has a tendency to dance around a bit so your configurations will vary. I normally print with the following slicer settings Layers and Perimeters
Layer height .15
Vertical shells 2
Solid layers 4 top and 2 bottom Infill
Fill Density .25
Infill 1
Solid infill every 6
Fill angle 45
Solid infill threshold area 70 Speed
Perimeters 50
Small perimeters 50
Infill 50
Solid infill 50
Top solid infill 50
Support material 60
Bridges 50
Gap fill 40
Travel 60 Filament and Temperature
I was printing with 1.75mm filament with a bed temperature between 95C to 110C and a hot end temperature of 220.

comments.text: Thank you for creating this!  It made no sense for me to have to take apart the machine for something that was quick to diagnose.  If anything, it will help buy some time.  I applaud you :)
comments.author: toyzealot

This is a low poly model of the Boston Dynamics Atlas robot as used in the DARPA Robotics Challenge Trials in December 2013 in Homestead, Miami. It is based off the model available as open source via the drcsim project (https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim) under a Apache 2.0 license.

The model is based on the meshes and URDF model available as open source on Bitbucket (see atlas_description). The following steps were taken to generate the model from the original URDF:

  • Generate simplified convex hull models for most links using MeshLab

  • Special treatment for fingers, making distal links of irobot hand fingers longer, so they do not float in midair

  • Special treatment for upper torso, generating multiple smaller convex hulls based on vertex selection in Blender

  • Edit URDF model to use manually determined fixed joint angles and use simplified meshes

  • Convert URDF to Collada using collada_urdf

  • Import Collada to Blender, add cube geometry in some places (feet, hands) to close gaps. Export to STL.

  • Run STL through netfabb cloud service for repair

  • Generate ascii stl using Blender and add author notice in first line

  • Upload to thingiverse
    • Scaling the model to 60mm and then printing laying on the back with a Replicator 2 gave satisfactory results. Thanks to FabLab Darmstadt for providing the opportunity to experiment with this.

Mounts a Fostex FT28D speaker and clip it into place with no screws required.  There is a small hole in the back of the sphere for a BNC or other audio connector.  Not sure how well this will fit other speakers.

Print sphere with full support and with the open end of the sphere up; this way, the support structure will be on the outside and easy to remove.  The open clip should be printed with full support as well.

comments.text: Did you end up using this as part of a larger speaker?  How did the tweeter sound in this enclosure?
comments.author: Jzatopa

comments.text: I printed out a couple of these for the Fostex FT28D.  I used it in a laboratory for simple sounds (tones, clicks, noises, etc), but not music.  I'm not sure how it would perform against a real enclosure for music; probably not as well.
comments.author: Jzatopa

For Display. This will hold a PrintRbot X assembly with the extruder upright on a table. It has 2 pegs that are a bit smaller than the holes on the X carriage.The weight of the side motor will jam it upright. The body is large, and has several faces that logos or text or labels could be used on. This was its first print.
I shouldn't have used the fan. I disabled it near the top and its fine from then on. Pictured here is my all plastic Printrbot X carriage model which I will explain in another posting.

If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Inspired by Gijs Birdsnest eggcup on Shapeways ( http://www.shapeways.com/model/174314/birdsnest-eggcup.html ) I decided to make a similar egg cup since I don't think Gijs made his model available. To keep it fair I didn't reference Gijs work when making this one. Gijs is much better. Mine ended up looking more like a tree in Autumn, so that's what I'm calling this one.

description.text:
I finally got done building and calibrating my version of smartrap. Because I had issues with slippage on Y axis I switched to belt design based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:290851 and also took the tensioner from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:143410. I had to change steps for unit for Y to 100 and for X to 186 to make it print correct. Also at higher speeds the base is not stable enought and I used ideas from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:260187. I also added a fan for ramps and some LEDS to print head. Maybe someone better at 3d modeling can help me incorporating a fix into X plate. Next I will print a LCD case on printer itself. Can someone suggest a suitable design for RepRapDiscount Smart Controller?
A small printing video can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vw8YTC2Fy5Q

comments.text: You've got the .stl of the rod support in Y axis? Because I wanted to use fishing line as well
comments.author: Muscles

comments.text: I'm going to try your z wobble solution. You happy with it so far?
comments.author: madmike8

comments.text: Yes its a lot better if you have a z screw that wobbles a lot. It was very clear that this solution cancel the vibration to X axis due to z wobble. Its not a very polished solution for smartrap, I basically used existing stuff from thingiverse but works just fine. I can make a short movie to see how it works.
comments.author: madmike8

comments.text: I implemented the z wobble backlash solution from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220037http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... along with Z Rod Constraint http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9864http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... Since these was done for 8mm screw I used some M8 to M5 nuts adapters that worked just fine. After the upgrade I printed the spool holder from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60352http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... to see how good the prints go. I was very impressed with the quality of the results. Also I tried a print with ABS with bed heated at 100C and it went without any heating problems. You must have a fan to blow over the RAMPS since things get hot in there :).
comments.author: ldanut

comments.text: I just assembled together various ideas from other great people from this community. I was working on it for about 2 weeks 1-2hours every evening after work. Fine tuning is the pain no matter what printer you make. Everything can be reused in any other printer you build. The wood base is very helpful to attach various stuff to printer like power plug, fan, wire clips or LCD.
comments.author: ldanut

comments.text:
Really great work ! Impressive.
Like with fbuenonet, I'm also going slowly to the same solutions :)
Soon an update with the wood plank back ( for shipping glass reason, but as we have it, better to use it, right ? ). It's more stable with a base.
I'm integrating this belt solution ( will just add the right holes) .
I like your switch ! I will try it.. was looking for a solution like this.
Can i steal some solutions you did ?
Thank you.
comments.author: smartfriendz

comments.text:
Problems with the fishingwire solution?
There are many printers that apply it without issues, like the tantillus and 3drichrap
comments.author: smartfriendz

comments.text: Fishing wire was working OK as long as you go slow. But I don't like slow. I have also a delta printer that is very fast and my plan was to get this printer as fast as possible. Initially on heated bed I had also sandwiched an aluminum plate. But it was too heavy for what Y axis structurally can support or fishing wire to move. X axis is light and there the fishing line works great as is at fast speeds but I couldn't make it work for Y axis no matter how tight was the wire. During a narrow wall printing where the printer vibrates a lot layers got shifter on Y. Maybe using directly the motor shaft to spin the wire is not good and we need to add a wire spool to increase the diameter. I didn't want to go this path since for me the belt was more appealing and not that expensive.
comments.author: orpheus

comments.text:
Directly on the saft is not the best idea indeed a spool is really needed in my opion. But a delta printer is much faster anyhow then a printer like the smartrap.
I really like the smartrap for its simplicity but its weaker in strenght then a prusa i3 for instance. If you run it at very high speeds you will run in all shorts of trouble especialy when you go higher in your print.
Please dont get me wrong about the smartrap and your version I really like them and they are great, but it wont be speedmonsters.
comments.author: ldanut

comments.text: Of course it will never be as fast as a delta mainly because of z axis. But I like trying to push the limits and make small adjustments to make it better. I liked a lot the design mainly because of simplicity and cleverness of design. If nothing else its a very good play ground to experiment new things on every aspect of it. Now I'm working o z wobble problem and I'm going to print this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220037http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... and this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217617http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... and this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9864http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... and see how it works. Next I would increase the distance between Y rods to add more stability there since that is another week point. After that who knows two heads ? :).
comments.author: orpheus

comments.text: I'm actually working on modifying the plate that holds the Z bearings to be buildable out of flat stock and so CNC-ed rather than printed.  My experiments after making 4 of these is that the base indeed can be more stable, but it could do with the Z rods further apart (which will add to the overall stability) to better accommodate a belt and/or linear gear.  All the bearings would be LM8UU but with pillow blocks.
comments.author: ldanut

comments.text: Very interesting your work. And hot bed for ABS! brilliant
comments.author: fbuenonet

3DHubs Copenhagen Champagne challenge.
We have decided to challenge you a bit. We will be serving champagne at the event the 16/04 and you will need something to drink out of. So you have to print your own champagne glass. We will provide the stl file for the glass, then all you have to do is print it.
And if it holds the champagne in and looks awesome you can win some fantastic prizes. The champange is provided by deluxlife.dk
Just placed everything on one plate.

This is just a combined single stl with all the parts.
Seems to print fine on a Replicator with raft and full support.

comments.text: Tried to print this out but print failed. Printed out original multplate $15 enclosure and it worked fine. Put it in netfabb and there were fatal errors that were not repairable. I am perplexed as you could print it and the file looks fine to me. Yet, it doesn't print past the first raft layer. This was on a replicator with replicatorg. Is that what you're using? Maybe it prints on other stuff but not replicatorg/marlin. I dunno....

description.text: Spool holder that's longer and slimmer than the original one to hold different spools

Since Makerbot was out of black white abs, right when I needed more, I ended up ordering spools off of Amazon.  The ABS is fine, but the spool that it came on were a different size and wouldn't fit on the holders that came with my makerbot.  So I took the one off the back of my makerbot and modeled myself a copy, but with a holder that's longer to hold the spool, and slim enough for the spool to actually get on it.
It's a little over 3.5in long and an inch and a half in diameter.
I've got two versions here - one has the whole holder as a single piece, but you'd have to print with raft support (I haven't tried it that way yet).  The other is in 2 pieces so it could be printed without any raft, but you have to glue them together.  I used this really awesome superglue that basically melts the abs together, and there's been no indication at all that it might give or break so far, and I've been printing on it for a while now.

title: Spiral Yarn Bowl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This simple little yarn bowl helps keep your ball of yarn from rolling about when you're knitting, crocheting, or otherwise yarning.

The spiral needs support to print properly and can be a little tricky to remove cleanly from the smallest areas.  I recommend using the upper part of the spiral for knitting from, as the pointiest bit of the spiral can tend to snag with the layer lines.  Sand the surfaces that may have yarn going through them well, so the yarn doesn't snag, and if necessary, carefully flame polish to return the filament to its original non-sanded colour.  
Make sure to print with sufficient infill and wall thickness: the spiral can be a little delicate otherwise, and you want it to have some decent weight to it...  If you find it still slides around when in use, attach some self-adhesive non-slip feet to the bottom, or use a piece of drawer/rug liner glued on, or use adhesive foam stickers.  
Check the scale before printing - this is scaled for a smallish bowl which neatly fits a 50 gram ball or cake of yarn.  For a 100 gram ball or if knitting from store-bought oblong skeins instead of cakes, you may want it a bit bigger.

comments.text: I have tried every way I can think of to get this to print.  On a raft, with supports, etc.
comments.author: GonzoG1964

comments.text: I printed at 10% infill (because I wasn't paying attention) and the bowl only weights 3oz and the tip of the spiral broke off while i was removing some of the extra support plastic. I'll probably remake with at least 20% infill because it's definitely to light and a little to fragile where the spiral is concerned. If someone wants it a little heaver either use higher infill or maybe adding a little felt or rubber to the bottom. This would also help it from sliding or moving while using.
comments.author: Megoman

comments.text: Hiya! We're in the process of purchasing a 3D printer - yay! I did pottery for a while and have made a few ceramic bowls recently. Was wondering if a plastic yarn bowl is heavy enough to not be pulled from the table when knitting. Then again, it won't break, like my ceramic ones.
comments.author: Arjaaa

comments.text: You'll want to use enough infill to give it a lot of weight, which will greatly increase your print time but will also increase the weight.  If you've got the money, definitely try Simplify3D, as it will let you say "100% infill up until 2cm high, then 20% infill after that" so you can make a really heavy base, but a lighter-weight body.  Putting little rubber feet on the bottom helps too.  :)

description.text: Inspired by the Balloon Powered Car, this is a Balloon Powered Hovercraft.

1) Inflate a balloon
2) While pinching the balloon shut, put the stem of the balloon over the inlet at the top of the hovercraft. This is tricky but it can be done.
3) Place on a smooth, flat surface.
4) The hovercraft will float a short distance above the surface until the balloon deflates.
Also useful for determining just how level your table, floor, etc. is, since if there is any slope to the surface whatsoever the hovercraft will drift downhill.
Won't work well on rough surfaces like carpet, grass, etc.

I made this thing. 0.25mm layer heights, 2 shells, 2 layers top and bottom, 10% infill. Some advice for makers:
The curve from the side to the top is severe, which makes each layer step in quite a lot, easy to get gaps. Also, 10% in fill makes it hard to get a smooth top in just two solid layers. So make sure you use enough top solid layers in order to get an air tight volume. Mine was leaky and inefficient.

author: Kawobei

description.text:
If you want to be steampunk, you have to have the right gear!
And the right gear is sure to be found somewhere in this collection.
This is a collection of different gears, designed for the benefit of my wife and several other people I know who like steampunk. These gears are intended to be purely decorative--I did not design them with any practical considerations at all (i.e. strength, meshing properly, etc.)

There are four types of spokes: spoke, double spoke, spiral, and wavy.
There are three types of teeth: round, pointed, and square. Round teeth are small and rounded. Pointed teeth are larger and come to a point at the tip. Square teeth are long and skinny with square ends and large spaces between teeth.
Gears come in four sizes: 1, 2, 3, and 4 inch (these are nominal sizes. The actual diameter with the teeth is larger).
All gears are 3mm thick
If you're counting, there are 48 total variations in this collection. I supplied a ZIP file containing all the STLs for convenience if you want to grab the bunch.
I'm open to suggestions for additional spoke and tooth templates if you have an idea which is really distinctive from something already here.

title: key hole slot (use as a negative space)

description.text: This is a generic concept to create a "keyhole" slot for your project that you want to hand on a wall by a screw or nail.  The idea is taken directly from the woodworking world, where you would use a keyhole router bit to plunge into a piece of wood, then move along the work piece once the router bit is submerged beneath the surface.

If you use this thing or a similar thing, you can use this as a negative space you can subtract from your wall-hanging thing. Use a boolean "difference" operation... or in tinkercad, assign this object the "hole" color and group it with your main thing. Works great! This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/5rcAYD0KB15

description.text: This is a prototype for a simple letterpress. Arrange the tiles, cover with ink, hold paper down firmly - hey presto! Font is OCR-A, designed to be clearly read by humans and machines. The .ODS is an OpenOffice / LibreOffice file which you can use to generate your own character. Read my blog about it at http://shkspr.mobi/blog/2014/04/3d-printed-letter-press/

• Created a spreadsheet (.ods attached).
  • Each square has a thick black border (space between the tiles)
  • Background is grey - the darker, the thinner the height of the tile.
  • Font is white - the lighter, the higher the letter stands from the tile.
  • Export to PNG.
  • Trim the excess in a graphics editor (GiMP) and ensure background is black.
  • FLIP THE FILE HORIZONTALLY!
  • Use png23d to create the .STL
  • Sample command png23d -v -f surface -t 0 -l 32 -w 100 -d 5 -O 1 -o stl Letter.png Letters.stl

title: Splined Idler Pully for Mini Kossel

description.text:
I already had some 623 bearings left over from another project so I wanted to use them here instead of buying F623 for the Mini Kossel (MK) I am assembling. The splined design allows  a crisp shoulder to be printed with no overhang issues and a symmetrical design.   
The printed texture of the spline and wheels create a grip surprisingly strong. Requires a well tuned printer.

• Print out 1 spline and 2 sides for each idler.
  • Snap together. I used pliers but a clamp or vise would work even better.
  • Insert bearings.
  • Enjoy.

A small, completely printable quadcopter printed on my Up! Plus 3D printer

Its reasonably straight forward. I made a few changes to the original, geared more toward FPV. The arms have been shortened by removing the extension, But the remaining pieces have been lengthened, The motor cups ESC tray have been lengthened by 14mm to accommodate a Turnigy 10A ESC comfortably. I have also changed the motor mount spacing to hold the Blue wonder 24g 1200Kv motor. All the wiring for these fit's nicely in the arms. To use the blue wonder motor you will need to drill 3mm holes in the sides of the cup to line up with the grub screws in the motor mount so you can get an allen key through to them. I bolted in the mount with M2 15mm bolts with washers underneath, screwed in from the underside. I have changed the base plate considerably, The arm couplers have had the hole for the wiring run straight through. Ive also done this with the Controller mounts and spaced them out a little more to account for the ABS shrinkage. Im using the KK2 board. The landing gear are the same. The canopy is where I have made the most changes to the original and its a tricky print. Ive added a Radome for a 5.8Ghz cloverleaf antenna, and a window for the VTx heatsink, Im using the small 200mw VTx from FPVHobby. The antenna mount component squeezes and fits underneath the cloverleaf to secure it. I used acetone/ABS slurry to fix it in place. Like I said its all pretty straight forward, all the modifications have been done in sketchup, and all printed parts have had a wash with acetone/ABS slurry for added strength. Ive not used the Gopro mount as my small motor choice doesnt have the lifting strength, Im using the Sony Kx-171 5V camera for FPV, the mount will be posted for this soon and attach to the canopy. My running gear is as follows;
24g Blue wonder 1200Kv motors
10A Turnigy ESC
KK2.0 controller
200Mw 5.8Ghz Vtx & Cloverleaf
Hobbyking Supersimple OSD
Sony Kx-171 5V cam
Hobbywing 3A UBEC
1800Mah 3S 20-30C Lipo
Master airscrew 7X4 props
Hitec Minima 6 Rx With this gear I get about 10 mins flight time if I'm carful with the throttle, its a solid little beast and its easy to transport. Enjoy CJ Addendum;
Just added the sketchup files as per request, I imported the originals downloaded from the PLSQ Leshy Quad, imported with the tim foltz sketchup plugin. I literally just updated my sketchup to the latest version so they were made in the last one. should be compatible with most versions though. Ive just uploaded the case for a Sony Kx-171 camera, the round dip in the back fits a standard disposable ear plug, cut down to about 4mm, this acts as a vibration dampener and keeps the camera snug, It can be a tricky print but it looks great. Its extremely protective, There is space for adjusting the screw for focusing the lens. The camera is held on the canopy at a 20 degree downward angle though this would be easy to change. Enjoy.

description.text: Sometimes gravity & alignment aren't enough to keep the bridge from hanging-up on descent, these keep the Z-rod nuts in their wooden slots to make sure the bridge descends everytime, no surprises.

I made these to clip on the back of the bridge so they wouldn't detract from the beauty of the Printrbot. After printing, remove support scaffolding under top clips. Place into upper wooden slots first & press down, then slide their feet (keepers) onto the Z-rods and press flat. The left side mounts inside the left tower, the right mounts on the back (remove long screw & nut to gain clearance, replace when done) see photos. You -do not- have to remove the pulley & belt. Both pieces have a slight overhang, so don't forget to enable "support" or "scaffolding" when slicing & remove them after printing. Use a fill density of at least 50%. Edit 9/3/2012:
  • Thing name corrected: now "Z-nut" (thanks tschutter, long night)
  • Z-nut Keeper L v2.stl uploaded: a) taller b) top clip no longer hits Z-rod (deleted v1)
  • Added photo: Z-nut Keeper L v2 inside left tower
  • Instructions improved slightly.

author: hillcrestmiddleschool

description.text:
A simple bracket for IKEA's awesome Jansjo LED gooseneck lamp.
The Jansjo lamp is perfect for focused lighting, I use a couple on my workbench to illuminate my printbed and shining a little extra light on electronics etc.
Unfortunately the desk version takes up valuable bench space and the clip version requires something to clip to (and is also much more expensive).
This thing is a quick hack to remedy that.

• Print
  • Insert the Jansjo's pegs into the small holes (the holes may need to be reamed a bit to fit)
  • Flip over and affix with the provided screws and washers
  • Mount to a flat surface
  • Achieve illumination!

comments.text: Just picked up 3 of these lamps for my shop.  I am printing a couple of these brackets to mount one near my grinder, bandsaw and drill press.  that way I have strong light where I need it.  Thank you for contributing to the safety of my shop.

author: met3dprint

description.text: Wall-E From Disney and Pixar's Wall-E. Created from multiple images from Google and then built in 123ddesign.

If you want to 3D print Wall-E you can follow these instructions: 1 Separate all his parts into separate stl files. (Main Body, Left Wheel, Right Wheel, Platform, Both arms are the same model, so you can use one arm twice.) 2 Use Makerware, or any alike, to prepare the model for print. 3 Increase the size of all parts by 2 times. 4 Adjust positioning to your standard. 5 Use an infill of 20%. Layer height, speed, and shells should be standard. 6 For all models but the arms and the body, print using supports and rafting, while printing the pieces tactically so you need less support. (Standard plastic) 7 When printing the arms and body you NEED dissolve-able filament. Print the main model with standard plastic and the supports/rafting with dissolve-able filament. You can select these settings within the Makerware software. 8 Using the dissolving agent and your preferred method of flack-removal, remove the rafts and support. 9 Put model together with whatever glue material you wish! 10 Enjoy your Model!!! 11 Any questions? Just email me at [email protected]
Also, if any asks you about the model, Just reference me! -Thanks and Enjoy!

author: hillcrestmiddleschool

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.

Water jet vacuum pump (Aspirator / Bunsen pump / Venturi pump).   
In its current state, it will happily implode an empty soda bottle, but the theoretical limit for such a pump is the vapour pressure of water.

1) Slice & print pump.stl using 100% infill for maximum strength
2) Sand and glue the pieces together using acetone. Paint the seams with acetone/ABS. The design is for a vacuum hose with an outer diameter of 9 m.m. and a water hose with an inner diameter of 13 m.m. The design can easily be modified to accomodate other dimensions. Insert the vacuum hose (a semi-rigid thick walled PVC tube will do), and connect a standard garden hose using a small hose clamp.

author: Nickolebart

description.text:
a simple frame body for a small quadrotor, designed around ~1/2" square towel bar and the KK flight control board.
You should be able to print and fly in the same day!

the towel bar I used is about 16mm wide - I included the OpenSCAD source so you can tweak it to your needs. Hardware is #6-32 nuts and flathead bolts for arms/frame and #4-40 for the control board. Use velcro straps in the slots to secure the battery. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29625 for motor mounts
See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28038 for landing struts
